title: Truffle stuck when deploy smart contract
body:
---------------------------

## Issue
I have a little problem deploying smart contract with ledger nano s as provider on ropsten. The script just remain stuck at first migration
```
Starting migrations...
======================
> Network name:    'ropsten'
> Network id:      3
> Block gas limit: 8000029 (0x7a121d)


1_initial_migration.js
======================

   Deploying 'Migrations'
   ----------------------
   > transaction hash:    0x1b85c85699b9f40798b5892a7492c303048915e80ac69803f94e617744769865
   ⠋ Blocks: 211          Seconds: 2829
```

This is my truffle configuration 
```
    ropsten: {
      provider: () => LedgerProviderRopsten,
      network_id: "*",
      gasPrice: web3.utils.toWei("3", "gwei"),
    },

```
## Steps to Reproduce

`truffle migrate --network ropsten`

## Expected Behavior
To migrate all the contract 
## Actual Results

In my example it wait for  Blocks: 211 but is stuck with first migration and don't run the next one

## Environment

* Operating System: Ubuntu 20
* Ethereum client: geth Version: 1.9.14-stable
* Truffle version (`truffle version`): 5.2.28
* node version (`node --version`): 12.8.0
* npm version (`npm --version`): 6.14.5

Interesting, can you tell us what you are using for `LedgerProviderRopsten`? Also, do you still get the same error when you remove the `gasPrice` field on your network settings? It should be optional and it would simplify troubleshooting. Let us know!
Hi @FilipLaurentiu is your project available somewhere for us to take a look? We're not sure what is causing this issue and would like to try to reproduce. Thanks!

> 
> 
> Hi @FilipLaurentiu is your project available somewhere for us to take a look? We're not sure what is causing this issue and would like to try to reproduce. Thanks!

[repository](https://github.com/FilipLaurentiu/LedgerExample)
I create a minimal repository to reproduce the issue. Just replace the rpc node with your node in 

> truffle-config.js 

and run 

> npm run deploy
Thanks for the reproduction steps @FilipLaurentiu! Sorry this has taken us a while to get to. One of us will take a look soon!

> Thanks for the reproduction steps @FilipLaurentiu! Sorry this has taken us a while to get to. One of us will take a look soon!

Thank you very much for response:+1:
Hi @FilipLaurentiu so sorry for the delay on this one! We're waiting to receive a dedicated hardware wallet for development purposes so we can test this properly. We'll keep you posted!

Hey again @FilipLaurentiu! I'm investigating your problem here and I wanted to verify that your use-case is supported by the device. Would you be able to link me to some docs describing how to use the ledger like you are doing? That would really help a lot in investigating your issue. Thanks!

> Hey again @FilipLaurentiu! I'm investigating your problem here and I wanted to verify that your use-case is supported by the device. Would you be able to link me to some docs describing how to use the ledger like you are doing? That would really help a lot in investigating your issue. Thanks!

I don't find any official document supporting this functionality, but as long as I use the [provider engine](https://www.npmjs.com/package/web3-provider-engine) with ledger as provider It should work. We use this provider for web3 in other parts of the project for smart contract interaction and its working with no problem.

So you can use this provider to interact with your contracts and send transactions? I wonder what could be going on because that is kind of what Truffle does in its internals. I'll look at that package. Thanks!

Would you be able to give me an example of using this provider that you've created to send a transaction? I just want something to verify it correctly working and then compare that to the migration issue.

Ah! One thing I noticed that could be the cause of the problem: try using our fork of `web3-provider-engine`. The package is called `@trufflesuite/web3-provider-engine`. I don't think Truffle is compatible with the most recent version of `web3-provider-engine`. We forked it a long time ago, I think because we are on an older version of `web3`. Try switching and let me know if you still encounter the same problem.

> Ah! One thing I noticed that could be the cause of the problem: try using our fork of `web3-provider-engine`. The package is called `@trufflesuite/web3-provider-engine`. I don't think Truffle is compatible with the most recent version of `web3-provider-engine`. We forked it a long time ago, I think because we are on an older version of `web3`. Try switching and let me know if you still encounter the same problem.

```
filip@filip-pc:~/Work$ yarn deploy
yarn run v1.22.5
$ truffle deploy -f 2 --to 2 --network ropsten --skip-dry-run --verbose-rpc --reset

Compiling your contracts...
===========================
> Everything is up to date, there is nothing to compile.



Starting migrations...
======================
> Network name:    'ropsten'
> Network id:      3
> Block gas limit: 8000029 (0x7a121d)


2_deploy_smart_contracts.js
===========================

   Deploying 'ContractName'
   -----------------------------
   > transaction hash:    0x1c4e8c1f14cbeb9470d7d4bc294ea3a5c447484c674c16bd22c4425c732d1923
   ⠴ Blocks: 64           Seconds: 701^C
```

Unfortunately, the same result. This is a temporal change or we should keep the  `@trufflesuite/web3-provider-engine` instead of `web3-provider-engine `?
Ah too bad, I thought it might be caused by an incompatible version of web3. Let me go ahead and I'll do some more investigation and get back to you. Thanks!

So can you give a simple example of how you would use the above setup to interact with a contract successfully?

Also, are you able to get this setup to work on a local test network like Ganache?

> So can you give a simple example of how you would use the above setup to interact with a contract successfully?
> 
> Also, are you able to get this setup to work on a local test network like Ganache?

We need truffle to support deploying smart contract using ledger. Just that. Smart Contract interaction is made with ledger connected to metamask.

I'm just trying to confirm that I can use this provider to send a transaction. So is it possible that you can provide me with a simple example of how I could use this to successfully send a transaction? This would be helpful so I can compare the successful and unsuccessful cases.

Hi @FilipLaurentiu I'm going to close this for issue maintenance, but if you get together an example of what you're trying to do with a ledger here so we can test it out more, we'd be happy to troubleshoot some more!

> Hi @FilipLaurentiu I'm going to close this for issue maintenance, but if you get together an example of what you're trying to do with a ledger here so we can test it out more, we'd be happy to troubleshoot some more!

and the truffle provider is configure like that:
```
    ropsten: {
      provider: () => LedgerProviderRopsten,
      network_id: "*",
      gasPrice: web3.utils.toWei("3", "gwei"),
    },

```
Thanks for the further information!  But, could you provide a simple example of a working transaction with this setup as suggested above?  It would be helpful in trying to debug this.

> > Hi @FilipLaurentiu is your project available somewhere for us to take a look? We're not sure what is causing this issue and would like to try to reproduce. Thanks!
> 
> [repository](https://github.com/FilipLaurentiu/LedgerExample)
> I create a minimal repository to reproduce the issue. Just replace the rpc node with your node in
> 
> > truffle-config.js
> 
> and run
> 
> > npm run deploy
@haltman-at 
is Ok ? https://github.com/FilipLaurentiu/LedgerExample

@FilipLaurentiu Yes, those are the instructions for an UNSUCCESSFUL transaction. We would like to see an example of running a simple transaction SUCCESSFULLY. I don't know about that provider setup and would like to ensure that it does indeed work. Thanks!

> @FilipLaurentiu Yes, those are the instructions for an UNSUCCESSFUL transaction. We would like to see an example of running a simple transaction SUCCESSFULLY. I don't know about that provider setup and would like to ensure that it does indeed work. Thanks!

Short example
https://github.com/FilipLaurentiu/WorkingLedgerExample
Thanks @FilipLaurentiu! I'll go ahead and see what I can find out.

Actually, I just looked at your example and it does not use the provider setup that you are trying to use in your main project. In other words, it does not demonstrate that the setup you are trying to use actually works. I can't help you troubleshoot until I can confirm that this actually does work correctly. Can you provide me with an example that demonstrates that your provider setup works for a simple transaction? Do you understand what I'm looking for?
@FilipLaurentiu closing this for issue maintenance, but feel free to get back to us and we'll be happy to re-open! Thanks!
Having the same issue at this point, all looks the same just using Rinkeby and HDWalletProvider(MNEMONIC, rinkebyNodeUrl); provider :(
@gnidan  can you reopen this?

> @gnidan can you reopen this?

Sure can! (Expect the team to follow-up requesting more information soon)
Can someone provide us with sample code and specific steps to reproduce this error?
